Nottingham\'s old centre is the Lace Market. It no longer makes much lace, but those old factories have been renewed
..as offices, flats, pubs.
The Victorian era red-brick factories contain here
a fashion college, insurance premises and lawyers offices.
Round here are a couple of clubs,
and restaurants (out of view, to the right).
Many Lace Market streets have all sorts of things to do.
This street has the renowned Broadway cinema, pubs and good restaurants.
This street with old cobbled stones contains two IT businesses.
Also my apartment (on the left), and the Anoki restaurant.
Down a short slope from the Lace Market is the old Market Square.
It is a popular venue for live bands and social events.
One tram stop up from the Market Square is the grand-looking Theatre Royal.
It tends to shows thrillers, and musicals
If you need a quiet afternoon to yourself, go to the Arboretum
Its a large park, near a tram stop, with private places to sit, and a restaurant.
The pond is right by the main entrance.
It has lots of ducks, interesting trees and an aviary.
The park has changing views, and much beauty.
This image shows part of the centre of the park, in early June.
The bell tower has Russian and Chinese scripts on the top, and canons taken by Nottinghamshire soldiers, from Crimea.
The canons are from the siege of Sevastopol in 1855.
The bell was stolen from Guangzhou in 1848.
It has significant spiritual importance (ringing it summons the attention of God)
